awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Connectivity and the Future of Remote Work
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in unpredicted and unprecedented levels of remote working. There is an urgency for understanding the critical issues related to creating a dynamic, flexible workforce through connectivity, technology adoption and design, and life-long learning. This Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) Planning Grant project will lead to new knowledge for optimizing the use of existing and emerging technology as well as identify technology gaps that will further improve remote work and the experience of the worker. The project team will promote the progress of science by developing a dynamic ecological model for interpreting how humans interact with other people and equipment to perform jobs remotely. This model will have potential to guide the study and design of remote work and the development of new technology for the near and foreseeable future. The project team will use outcomes from this project to inform the design of a full FW-HTF research proposal.  This project will advance the national prosperity and welfare by addressing issues impacting future remote work within the context of life-long learning, access and inclusion at multiple levels, and a fundamentally dynamic perspective on work and productivity. 

This FW-HTF project leverages the expertise of social scientists, engineers, and health professionals to plan a dynamic ecological model that will maximize benefits and minimize problems in the ever-expanding and evolving landscape of work. Project objectives include: 1) Identify characteristics of work that are or can be done remotely; 2) Create measures of productivity that flexibly meet the employers’ and remote workers’ needs; 3) Identify the major mental and physical stressors affecting remote workers; and 4) Identify current and future major technologies that make remote work possible.  The project uses a mixed-methods sequential design approach to accomplish these goals. The project team will begin with secondary data analysis of the nationally representative Pew Survey of Work Patterns During The Pandemic. Informed by the results of the secondary analysis, they will conduct workshops with managers and interviews with workers from companies varying in size and industry (e.g. education, service, manufacturing), which will touch on similar topics, but from each groups’ perspective.  Finally, the team will develop a survey instrument that will be administered to a nationally representative sample through the University of Michigan’s Survey of Consumer Attitudes ( a component of the Leading Economic Indicators). The nation is in the midst of a natural experiment that can provide insights to how it may be possible to optimize the potential of remote work in terms of productivity and worker well-being. This planning grant will provide the foundation for further research that can capitalize on that natural experiment to the benefit of national health, prosperity, and welfare.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background: This project focuses on Connectivity and the Future of Remote Work. We use the term “connectivity” in its broadest meaning to include not just hardware and software but also how that technology affects the ways that people work -- for better and for worse. We are concerned about not just physical access to technology but the ability of people to quickly understand and utilize that technology to better their lives both on and off the jobs. We are concerned with identifying socio-economic barriers to the use of this technology and how best to maximize the mental and physical health of people working remotely. Remote work offers unique potential to reach beyond geographic and social boundaries but also may increase those boundaries.  To maximize the potential of all workers and thus the productivity of society, we must attend to all aspects of the job and the worker and thus identify how best to enrich the potential of all workers and at the same time overcome constraints they may face. Attention to all aspects of the job, worker and work methods are necessary to successfully meet the challenges of work in the future. This includes fundamental understanding of individual workers, work teams, workplaces, and work organizations in the context of future work and future technology.

Approach: To better understand the impact and future of remote work we address four main objectives. First, we identify characteristics of work that are or can be done remotely. Second, we explore different ways of measuring productivity in order to create relevant assessments of productivity for remote workers. Third, we identify the major mental and physical stressors affecting remote workers. Finally, we identify the current and potential for future technologies that make remote work possible.

In order to achieve our objectives we employed a mixed-methods approach. We start with secondary data analyses of the 2020 Pew Research survey “How the Coronavirus Has and Hasn’t Changed the way Americans Work”. Next we developed a survey instrument that was administered to nationally representative sample through the University of Michigan’s Survey of Consumer Attitudes. Lastly, we conducted a series of semi-structured virtual interviews with employers and employees from diverse backgrounds.

Significant findings:

Survey Data Findings

  • Education appears to be one of the most important factors in the ability to work remotely. Seventy percent of respondents without a bachelor’s degree said they were working in person and 52% said their job could not be done from home. By comparison, 41% of those with a bachelor’s degree were working in person and only 19% said their work could not be done from home.
  • In our SCA survey, 37% of those sampled expressed a preference for working remotely all or most of the time. Another 30% indicated that they preferred some of the time, but 33% indicated that they prefer to rarely or never work remotely. Women had a stronger preference for working remotely all or most of the time than males (46% versus 34%). Only those in the 18-24 year range expressed greater preference for in-person work than older workers: 50% preferred working remotely rarely or never compared to roughly 30% in all other age groups
  • Sixty-eight percent of male and 80% of female remote workers felt anxious or stressed some or all of the time. Twenty-nine percent of workers felt isolated some or all of the time.

Semi-structured Interview Findings

  1. Effect of personality type: Nearly all participants mentioned that personality type plays a major role in whether or not an individual would thrive in a remote work environment. These participants indicated that whether someone is introverted or extroverted would influence where they would do their best work.
  2. Awareness of inequity among coworkers related to resources: Each participant was aware that although they may have access to childcare, home environments with spaces to set up a home office, and the technology needed to do their work, many others do not have those resources.
  3. Importance of relationships: Each of our participants stressed the importance of relationships with coworkers in both the remote and face-to-face workplace. One director felt that it was important to be able to speak face-to-face - not online or over the phone - with staff to resolve emerging issues. Another participant indicated it was important for staff to not miss an opportunity to have input into the directors thinking and be recognized for that input.

Impact: The impact of this work will result in the development of transformative research questions focused on how emerging technologies can lead to greater human and technological connectivity, mitigate the challenges of, and amplify the positive aspects of remote work.
